Literature Review: The exploration of novel colloidal food ingredients, particularly protein complexes and conjugates, has garnered significant attention in the field of food science and technology. These ingredients are formed through the combination of proteins with polysaccharides and/or polyphenols, leveraging covalent or noncovalent interactions to enhance or introduce new functional properties. This literature review delves into the formation, functionality, and potential applications of these innovative ingredients, emphasizing their role in stabilizing emulsions, controlling lipid digestion, encapsulating bioactive ingredients, modifying textures, and forming films. Proteins, polysaccharides, and polyphenols each bring unique functional attributes to the table. Proteins are renowned for their emulsifying and gelling capabilities, polysaccharides for their thickening and stabilizing effects, and polyphenols for their antioxidant and antimicrobial properties. When these components are combined into complexes or conjugates, the resultant colloidal ingredients exhibit multifunctionality that can be tailored for specific applications in food products. The formation of protein-polysaccharide complexes and conjugates has been extensively studied. For instance, the Maillard reaction, a non-enzymatic browning process, is a common method for creating covalent conjugates between proteins and polysaccharides, enhancing their emulsifying properties and thermal stability (Dickinson, 2003). Noncovalent interactions, such as electrostatic complexation, have also been explored for their ability to form stable complexes under specific pH and ionic strength conditions (Schmitt et al., 1998). These complexes have been shown to improve the texture and stability of food products, such as yogurts and sauces. Protein-polyphenol conjugates, on the other hand, are primarily formed through covalent bonding, often via enzymatic or chemical methods. These conjugates have demonstrated enhanced antioxidant activity and improved functional properties, such as increased solubility and emulsifying capacity (Rawel et al., 2005). The encapsulation of bioactive ingredients using protein complexes and conjugates has emerged as a promising application, offering protection against degradation and controlled release in the gastrointestinal tract (Chen et al., 2006). This approach has been particularly beneficial for the delivery of sensitive bioactive compounds, such as vitamins and polyphenols, in functional foods. The stabilization of emulsions is another critical application of protein complexes and conjugates. These colloidal ingredients can form interfacial layers around oil droplets, preventing coalescence and improving the physical stability of emulsions (McClements, 2004). Moreover, the ability of protein-polysaccharide complexes to control lipid digestion has been investigated, with potential implications for the development of low-calorie and satiety-enhancing foods (Singh et al., 2009). The modification of food textures using protein complexes and conjugates has also been explored. These ingredients can influence the rheological properties of food systems, leading to desired textures in products such as gels, foams, and films (Foegeding et al., 2002). Additionally, the formation of edible films and coatings from protein complexes and conjugates has been studied for their potential to extend the shelf life of perishable foods by providing barriers to moisture, oxygen, and microbial growth (Krochta & De Mulder-Johnston, 1997). Despite the promising applications of protein complexes and conjugates, there are still challenges and research needs in this area. The rational design of these colloidal ingredients requires a deep understanding of the interactions between proteins, polysaccharides, and polyphenols, as well as the impact of processing conditions on their functionality (Norton & Frith, 2001). Future research should also focus on the scalability of production methods, the safety and regulatory aspects of novel ingredients, and their sensory impact on food products. In conclusion, protein complexes and conjugates represent a versatile and innovative class of colloidal food ingredients with the potential to revolutionize the food industry. By harnessing the unique properties of proteins, polysaccharides, and polyphenols, these ingredients can be designed to meet the growing demand for nutritious, sustainable, and healthy foods. Continued research and development in this field will be essential to unlock the full potential of protein complexes and conjugates in food applications.
